p: Seven studies, involving 182 patients, evaluated the efficacy of antiviral therapy for HBV-GN. We evaluated the CR and total remission (CR+PR) rates after treatment with a fixed-effect model ( Fig 2). There was no clinical and statistical heterogeneity in total remission of all trials (I 2 = 0%, P = 0.80), and the test for the overall effect was significant ( P<0.00001). The total remission rate of proteinuria was obviously higher in the antiviral treatment group than in the control group in all studies (OR = 10.48, 95% CI: 4.60−23.89). The antiviral treatment significantly affected CR in all trials (OR = 11.64, 95% CI: 5.17−26.21). There was no heterogeneity between data sources in the CR of all trials (I 2 = 23%, P = 0.26). The χ 2 test of heterogeneity was not significant in the CR evaluation from the CCTs (I 2 = 9%, P = 0.36, OR = 8.47, 95% CI: 3.67−20.80). We conducted a sensitivity analysis of all studies ( S3 Fig). Our analysis determined that the study by Sun’s study[ 17] and Panomsak’s study[ 20] was the source of heterogeneity.
